abstract: New York City Police Commissioner William J Bratton and predecessor Raymond J Kelly spar over Police Dept's murder and shooting totals, with Kelly accusing department of altering records to portray city as safer; comments undermine Mayor Bill de Blasio's claims that city remains safe despite more liberal policing tactics and represent sudden escalation of long-simmering tension between former and current commissioners.
lead_paragraph: Former Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly told a radio interviewer that a recent tally of major crimes was unreliable. His successor, William J. Bratton, said Mr. Kelly had offered no proof.

headline.main: New York Police Commissioner and Predecessor Spar Over Accuracy of Crime Data
headline.print_headline: Bratton Battles His Predecessor on Crime Tally

snippet: Former Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly told a radio interviewer that a recent tally of major crimes was unreliable. His successor, William J. Bratton, said Mr. Kelly had offered no proof.
